answers.answer: For starters they will put you on thyroid replacement hormones and probably run a complete set of labs and an ultrasound.  Since you have a nodule they need to watch it closely.If you can't get a good endo (who specializes in thyroids - not just diabetes) and who accepts medicaid check into ENTs.  Many also treat thyroids.I'm sorry for all you have been going through.

question: tsh was .002 over a year ago. Immediately treated with radioactive iodine. Had to insist on follow up blood test by uncooperative internist who did treatment, over a year later.  Said took long time to kill nodule my size, test showed thyroid is coming back up to a normal level(would not tell me level or give copy of bloodwork). While hospitalized with copd, pulmonologist aked how throid follow up doing, freked when found out wasn't any, and ordered bloodwork.  Now tsh at 25.547.  Is trying to find endocrinologist that accepts medicaid to refer me.  What will they do now?  Surely you don't get radioactive iodine for tsh that low and then again when it goes high?  Iodine treatment was extemely painful, and difficult for about three months afterwards, with pain and swelling in neck, high temperature all the time, especially at night. Please tell me what would normally be done next under these cicumstances.
title: thyroid gone crazy after radioactive iodine
